location.name: Sri Lanka
location.activity-description: implemented by the Ministry of Environment, Sri Lanka.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1). Number of joint initiatives between Agencies, Private Sector and NGOs formulated through the National Invasive Species Specialist Group & National Focal Point on Invasive Alien Species control 2). Availability of Invasive Alien Species policy and strategy 3). Availability of mechanism to maintain and update the data base on Invasive Alien Spices in Sri Lanka. 4). Invasive Alien Species act is developed for cabinet approval

baseline.comment: 1). Four joint activities implemented through inter-agency participation, with no private sector involvement (2011) Source: project document 2). Working draft of the national Invasive Alien Species policy; working draft of the national Invasive Alien Species strategy and action plan ( 2011) Source: project document 3). National data base is not available for Invasive Alien Species in Sri Lanka. ( 2011) Source: project document 4). No exist for Invasive Alien Species in Sri Lanka ( 2011) Source: project document

target.comment: 1). 5 ( only for this year ) 2). Draft policy and strategy are available 3). Draft database and developed mechanism is available 4). Develop draft Act and review by the public

actual.comment: 1). 0 2). Achieved target 3). No progress due to project management and institutional capacity issues 4). Preliminary draft act developed. But act was not reviewed by the public

target.comment: 1). 5 ( only for this year ) 2). Finalized Policy and Strategy documents available 3). Finalized database and developed mechanism is available 4). Cabinet paper develop on proposed act

actual.comment: 1) 5 Joint initiatives established with key stakeholder agencies of the project to conduct IAS baseline assessments. This is the first step to develop and implement pilot projects incorporating ecosystem approach to IAS management 2) IAS National Coordination Committee is functioning with the involvement of key stakeholder agencies. IAS Policy and Strategy has been re-drafted as recommended by the MTR of the project and ready for Cabinet approval. Secretary to the ministry has instructed to include the IAS National Action Plan along with the Policy and Strategy for Cabinet approval. IAS National Action Plan will be finalized within December 2015. National Invasive Species Specialist group was expanded and continuing to provide technical advises. 3) IAS data base is being prepared. Initial arrangements are made ( human and IT resources) to maintain and update the database by national focal point. 4) IAS Act has to be re drafted as recommended by MTR. Process started with the support of a legal consultant and first draft will be available in first quarter of 2016.

location.name: Colombo
location.activity-description: The programme is nationally implemented by the Sustainable Energy Authority and is targeted to benefit whole citizens of Sri Lanka

result.title: Objective
result.description:
Reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the use of fossil fuel for thermal energy generation in the Sri Lanka industrial sector
Removal of barriers to the realization of sustainable biomass plantation, and adoption of biomass-based energy technologies in Sri Lanka

indicator.title: Indicator 1

baseline.comment: Limited experience with BETs in industry;

target.comment:
At least 12 companies are operating BETs and another 12 companies have detailed feasibility studies completed or started installation of gasifier systems by the end of the project (post-project direct emission reduction) in particular gasification with total capacity of 25.7 MWth and 1 MWe, resulting in fossil fuel savings of about 295,178 GJ annually, 4,680 MWh of electricity and direct emission reduction (cumulative over 10 year lifetime) of 252 ktCO2
Indirect emission reduction impacts between 609 (bottom-up) and 1,378 ktCO2 (top down)

actual.comment:
There are 10 companies identified as per the inception report (who have pledged co-financing) in relation to the outcome 4. It was expected to add more partners.
Of these, three gasifier systems (two Aitken Spence hotels and Apollo Marine International Ltd.) are in operation, and had initiated activities before the project had become operational. The plantation companies listed however are more concerned about implementing fuelwood plantations and improving supply chains. Almost all the tea processing factories listed now use biomass, but for drying purposes, not as gasifiers. The industrial sector (Brandix) has implemented a new plant but not with biomass gasifier.
There are six other entities too who were mentioned in the inception report as probable candidates. Of them one company (Lion Brewery) is already considering installing a biomass run plant, but not opting for gasifier technology.
However, there are a number of other companies that have already installed and some more have planned to introduce the BET’s for thermal energy requirements during the project period (without project interventions). Majority of them are not Gasifiers as the project has proposed. It is noted that the industry prefers other technologies (direct fired boilers, industrial heaters) over gasifiers to meet their thermal needs. Therefore project needs to review the technology selection to support industry requirements.
This concern was highlighted at the project core group meeting as well as the last steering committee meeting, and it was suggested to take up the matter at the MTR time and propose appropriate changes to reflect the changed baseline situation and follow the recommendations therein.
With the MTR recommendations, the project is working on updating the activities and Outputs. Subsequently, related indicators will be reflected in the project log frame. Technology related issues will be addressed as well during this adaptive management process. Industry preferences are in biomass fired conventional boilers with modern controlling and feeding systems with co-generation and tri-generation options, industrial dryers, etc.
In order to select committed partners for demonstration projects, Project has initiated discussion with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce (not gone ahead with newspaper advertisement as proposed earlier, as the advertisement by SLSEA for registering supply chain operators received a poor response). Once the technology concern is addressed to project expects to work with the industry on assisting in feasibility studies and technology demonstration.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: A set of approved and implemented policy instruments that promote and support the use of sustainably produced fuel wood in industrial thermal applications.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No. of approved and implemented policy instruments that promote and support the use of sustainably produced fuel wood in industrial thermal applications) by EOP

baseline.comment: Various barriers limit in practice the wider-scale application of BETs by industry

target.comment: One conducive policy-regulatory framework is in place with appropriate incentives for the production, transportation and use of biomass for energy in industrial and commercial establishments

actual.comment:
Initial background study on identifying biomass energy related rules regulations and policies conducted.
This will be the base document for the next stages of the activity.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 1.1: Established and enforced mechanisms for effective cooperation between various government agencies and private sector involved in (regulating) fuel wood production, supply and use for thermal energy generation
Inter-Ministerial Committee on Renewable Energy (biomass) established (ICRE) by year 2

baseline.comment: No ICRE

target.comment: ICRE established by year 2

actual.comment: Not initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of government agencies that actively participate in ICR by year 3

target.comment: At least 6 agencies participating by year 3

actual.comment: ICRE is not formed as yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of approved and implemented policies that were formulated and enforced by BEASL by EOP

baseline.comment: Institutional and individual members

target.comment: 3 policy recommendations made and endorsed by ICRE/ Ministry of Environment and Renewable Energy

actual.comment: Linked with the preceding activity. The context may change

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Establishment of a biomass division in SEA

baseline.comment: No dedicated biomass division

target.comment: One biomass division established by year 4 for enforcement of strategy

actual.comment: SLSEA is taking action to formalize the cell and its implementation mechanism to accommodate requirements of the new energy policy and the strategy on biomass energy.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Output 1.2: Completed awareness raising campaigns and general trainings
Number of awareness raising events and trainings organized

target.comment: About 18 events

actual.comment:
05 events carried out during this period
1. Workshop on development of Provincial Action Plan for Central province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Kandy on Dec, 12 & 13, 2014, 84 participants)
2. Workshop on energy productivity improvement
Northern Province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Jaffna District Secretariat on Dec 19, 2014, 42 participants)
3. Biomass Energy- Present Status and Future Trends Senior officers of BOI Zones and technical staff of current biomass users and potential biomass users in BOI Zones of Biyagama, Katunayake, Horana, Seethawaka and Mawathagama. (@ Biyagama on Jan 29, 2015; 80 participants)
4. Workshop on energy productivity improvement
Northern Province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Kilinochchi District Secretariat on Feb 07, 2015, 47 participants
5. Workshop on development of Provincial Action Plan for Uva province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Badulla on April, 6 & 7, 2015, 72 participants)

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of trained officials by 2016

target.comment: 450 national and local-level officials trained

actual.comment: 325 officials trained

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description:
Output 1.3: Proposed, approved and implemented policies/incentive schemes for fuel switching
Policy brief developed on the real cost of fossil fuel subsidy

target.comment: Report on pros and cons on fossil fuel subsidies published by year 1, resulting in a at least one policy paper and presentation to Treasury officials through SLSEA

actual.comment:
The fossil fuel subsidies existed during project development period has been withdrawn. But there was no firm fossil fuel pricing methodology nor policy governing it in operation, but fuel prices have been brought up as a political issue. Project has been working on obtaining services of a suitable consultant to carry out a study, but this volatile situation was not the opportune time.
The establishment of the new government in January 2015, the fossil fuel prices have been changed and the government is planning to introduce transparent, cost reflective pricing formula for fossil fuel as well. Now the country is again at a verge of parliamentary election, through which a new government will be established. The subsidy effect (if any) will be analyzed to take appropriate future actions, when the current scenario is stabilized.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Number of private sector parties actively involved in BEASL by year 5

baseline.comment: 5 Institutional, and 75 individual members

target.comment: Membership doubled by Year 5 since project inception;

actual.comment: This activity was found to not suit the current context. It will be reviewed post MTR as the project explores possibility of widening the participation of energy sector entities to achieve project outputs. There are other organizations such as Sri Lanka Energy Managers Association (SLEMA), National Cleaner Production Centre (NCPC) that have been identified by the project and recommended by the MTR pane. Therefore, an evaluation of capabilities of all these entities that match with project requirements and getting them involved in delivery is expected.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Long term strategy for biomass energy government established

baseline.comment: No strategy

target.comment: Strategy and Action Plan endorsed by SLSEA Board by year 3.

actual.comment:
SLSEA is very keen on promoting biomass energy technologies and developing a supporting environment for that. Despite the slow progress of the project, SLSEA has been active on biomass energy issues.
Post MTR, the Institutional context has been changed now and the SLSEA has been shifted to the Ministry of Power & Energy from the Ministry of Environment. MOPE has recently launched a new energy policy (2015 – 2025) for the country, supported by SLSEA inputs on biomass. This policy has identified activities on biomass energy based on the SLSEA plans including project activities. Hence SLSEA’s long term strategy will be formulated within this context. The project will support SLSEA and MOPE with this work.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Rating of the training events by participants

target.comment: 80% rates the training events as good/excellent

actual.comment: Only one of the event of the above 5 (event # 3) is rated. The project will contact the participants 6 months post training to find out the usefulness of the training.

indicator.title: Indicator 12
indicator.description:
Number of new industries that use biomass as an energy source
Incentive schemes for use of fuel wood for energy generation approved by 2016

target.comment:
At least 12 but target will be set by March 2014.
Integrated incentive scheme for biomass-for-energy production and use, implemented by agencies participating in ICRE

actual.comment:
No demonstration plants initiated with project inputs as yet. However, there are number of private sector initiatives in place. SLSEA has reported that there are about 180 biomass driven applications are in operation. Project is planning to work with Chamber of Commerce to identify committed plants to demonstrate new technologies beyond the business as usual case.
Not initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 13
indicator.description:
Output 1.4 Existing policies on fuel switch enhanced and implemented.
Amounts of loans guaranteed by Sustainable Guarantee Facility (SGF)

baseline.comment: Guarantee facility is operational however restricted to other RE (non-biomass)

target.comment: Loans to the amount of LKR 400 million are guaranteed by year 5

actual.comment:
Sustainable guarantee fund has been established in the SLSEA to provide guarantee facilities to any suitable energy project (both energy efficiency and renewable energy).
The project will now work with biomass energy projects who have applied for assistance yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 14
indicator.description: Number of applicants to the SGF

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: 40 applicants have applied to the fund

actual.comment: No applications pertaining to biomass energy projects have sought assistance of the SGF yet. With the expansion of project activities, more information on SGF to be shared with the intended industry segments.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced knowledge of and improved support network for sustainable fuel wood production

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Hectarage of sustainable fuel wood production

baseline.comment: Hectarage to be determined in surveys

target.comment: Hectarage needed for supplying demo projects (outcome 4) with fuel wood 2,229 ha established as new plantation models by year 3

actual.comment: The basic arrangements to conduct a biomass resource survey are currently ongoing. Once the survey is concluded in early 2016, the project will be in a position to identify available land to establish demonstration plantations.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 2.1: Prepared and disseminated information and knowledge products on fuel wood growing (models)
Number of surveys undertaken
Publication of handbook on sustainable approaches to biomass growing models

baseline.comment:
Info available at NGOs and government by studies undertaken before 2011
0

target.comment:
Surveys conducted in 10 regions on biomass resources, use, land and land use plus survey on current management practices, socio-economic benefits and challenges by 2012.
Handbook published by year 1

actual.comment:
During a stakeholder consultative workshop, it was decided to conduct a complete survey on biomass resource, use, land and land availability plus survey on current management practices, socio-economic benefits and challenges in 11 districts. These 11 districts were selected based on the supply and demand of the biomass. The duration of the survey will be for 9 months period.
The preliminary work is currently ongoing to select a suitable service provider to conduct the survey.
A consultant was hired to provide technical inputs for the survey.
Data and information collection process is ongoing to develop the handbook on sustainable approaches to biomass growing models.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 2.2: Tested and implemented supportive regulations and policies for sustainable fuel wood production
Number of lease procedures published and used by investors
Certification scheme of sustainable fuel wood established
CCB subsidy revived as a project supported pilot in three districts (Kurunegala, Puttlam, Gampaha)
Number of applicants to the scheme
Post-project action plan

baseline.comment:
0
0
CCB subsidy suspended due to poor uptake by farmers and high delivery cost to state
CCB provides subsidy for gliricidia intercropping
N/A

target.comment: Lease rates, lease procedures and example contracts published by 2015. Certification scheme established by 2014. Disbursement of subsidy by CCB at least 25% of coconut cultivators in three districts. Number of applicants has tripled since project inception by year 5 Post-project action plan formulated by 2015 for replication of the new approaches

actual.comment:
A preliminary study on government land approval procedures depending on the ownerships, land lease rates and lease procedures is ongoing to draft the
example lease rates and lease procedures for stakeholder validation.
With reference to 2014 PIR, the delayed start of the project was explained and Considering the time factor for developing a certification scheme during the project lifetime, Lead Technical Officer of the project decided to go for a process of developing criteria and indicators for sustainably produced fuel wood. Through a LoA, Sri Lanka Standards Institution (SLSI) was assigned to develop criteria and Indicators for sustainably produce fuel wood. First working group meeting held in May 2015 to draft the initial document. This will be reviewed and updated during the next working group meeting. It is expected to initiate the pilot the scheme by mid-2016.
At the time the project was designed, the Coconut Cultivation Board operated a subsidy scheme of LKR 4,000/ac for growing Gliricidia in coconut lands. However, in 2011, this subsidy scheme had been withdrawn due to poor uptake by the farmers.
During the Inception Workshop, CCB had agreed to revive a project-supported pilot subsidy scheme for Gliricidia cultivation in the coconut triangle (districts of Gampaha, Kurunegala and Puttalam). There was no follow-up on this initiative, and the CCB had not launched this programme.
The project is following up with CCB, who agreed to explore the possibility of incorporating Gliricidia as a component in its animal husbandry subsidy scheme, and to explore ways of mobilizing the communities under the CCB’s Kapruka Societies to enhance Gliricidia cultivation.
Not initiated yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Output 2.3: Suitable growing models and biomass species for fuel wood production researched and demonstrated in sustainable production demonstrated
Improved growing models and identified best growing approaches for suitable fuel wood species
Improved and expanded sustainable fuel wood production

target.comment: Field trial reports on growing models and at least 3 wood species other than gliricidia The gasifier pilot demonstration projects (Outcome 4) as well as other market demand provided with sufficient sustainably and viably produced fuel wood

actual.comment:
Information collection and preliminary studies are ongoing to establish field activities in early 2016
Not yet commenced.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Output 2.4 Completed awareness raising campaigns and specific training programmes for key stakeholders on growing of species for fuel wood production
Number of trainings and awareness creating events carried out
Rating of training and community level events

target.comment:
About 40 events held in various places in Sri Lanka with 20 participants each and 120 training days at community level (with 40 participants each);
80% rate workshops and events as good/excellent

actual.comment:
Training need assessment is ongoing. It is expected to initiate the training module development by end 2015 and training will commence in 2016.
N/A

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Improved confidence among industrial and banking sector on the feasibility, stability and economic benefits of sustainable fuel wood supply chains

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of supply chains developed in a feasible way

baseline.comment: Supply chains meet constraints

target.comment: At least six supply chains developed that are sustainable on the longer term

actual.comment:
The study on the current status of biomass energy has been concluded. This study has recorded that there are well established supply chains feeding industrial zones of Biyagama, Horana and Seethawaka (supplying 820 tons of biomass per day), as well as several large industries located outside industrial zones and tea factories. Fuel is supplied as mainly wood logs, wood chips, and saw dust/rice husk). Several facilities that convert wood logs to chips also established to feed the demand. Prices of different types of fuel and supply mechanisms have been recorded. The major concerns now prevail in the industry are, sustainability of the wood supplies, modes of optimizing existing chains to get the best outcome from the resources involved, and identification of further mechanizations to improve the efficiency of operation and quality of the product. This information will be used to plan future activities in a more focussed manner.
SLSEA has published a newspaper and web advertisement to get supply chain operators listed with them, but received a poor response. However, with the Trainings and awareness activities conducted the project has identified key players. However, smaller grass root level organizations need more attention and that gap will be filled by the Trainers trained at the TOT on supply chain development. SLSEA is planning activities on this regard.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 3.1:Proposed, approved and implemented policies and incentive schemes for sustainable fuel wood supply improved,
Enabling policy and incentive scheme formulated and approved
Number of applicants scheme

target.comment: Enabling policy approved by year 2 and incentive scheme approved by year 3; At least 15 applicants to the scheme by 2016

actual.comment:
Not commenced yet.
Not commenced yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 3.2: Completed training & outreach programmes for key stakeholders and published and disseminated knowledge products
Number of training events and rating of stakeholder participation
Rating of trainings and workshops by participants
Guidelines on supply chain development established; Number of companies that use the guidelines

actual.comment:
Services of an international consultant on supply chain development has been procured to bring in international experience and exposure and enhance local knowledge base to conduct training in the national level.
Following were conducted with the inputs from him.
1. A 3 day Training of Trainers program for 30 participants - Government stakeholders, university lecturers, industrialists, participants from community level plantation organization (@ Colombo, May 14 -16, 2015, 28 participants)
2. Training workshops for industrialists - Engineers or Managerial level employees with higher diploma or equivalent qualifications, who are involved in biomass supply chain activities in industries (@ Colombo, May 12, 2015, 23 participants)
3. Training workshops for industrialists - Engineers or Managerial level employees with higher diploma or equivalent qualifications, who are involved in biomass supply chain activities in industries (@ Negambo, May 19, 2015, 10 participants)
4. Seminar for policy and financial sectors - Senior/ managerial level employees related to policy, planning and financial sector organizations (@ Colombo, May 21, 2015, 30 participants)
Need to evaluate the information.
Not commenced yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Output 3.3 Six sustainable biomass supply chains established and operational
Number of feasibility studies and bankable proposals prepared; Number of biomass supply chains established
Information exchange forum established among supply industry

target.comment: Ten feasibility studies prepared, of which 8 have resulted in bankable proposals and 6 have started operations Forum established with at least 15 participating members; 6 of which are newly established suppliers by 2016

actual.comment:
No feasibility studies commenced as yet.
Not commenced yet.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Enhanced knowledge of, access to, and maintenance skills of biomass energy technologies

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of companies implementing BETs (gasification, fuel switching, EE improvements

target.comment:
At least 12 companies implement BETs, directly supported by the project by 2016;
Number of companies all over Sri Lanka that use BETs (t.b.d. in 2 surveys, baseline and end of project)

actual.comment: SLSEA is in the process of collecting baseline information. They have reported that 180 BET plants are reported as at present (excluding Tea sector)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Output 4.1: Twelve implemented, operational and monitored fuel wood thermal energy projects
Number of feasibility studies and project designs
Number of companies with operational BETs

baseline.comment:
9 companies have expresses willingness to participate (see co-fin letters)
0

target.comment:
About 24 companies have carried out identification and completed feasibility studies by 2017, of which have resulted in operational BETs and improved wood storage in 12 companies.
12 companies have operational BETs by 2017

actual.comment:
Not commenced yet
Discussions have been initiated with Ceylon Chamber of Commerce to identify suitable demonstration projects
The status of demonstration activities under output 4 was described against the project goal, which also based on the same fact. Although the project has mentioned BETs in general, in describing the project goal, there are various technology choices were recommended by the project during the project inception workshop apart from gasifiers alone. However, it was learnt that the industry needs have changed. By taking the advantage of MTR recommendations, the project shall promote various biomass energy technologies (overall goal of CO2 reduction by fuel switching will not affect by the technology choice, as long as the process and the supply of fuelwood is sustainable).
This anomaly needs to be addressed and resolved before engaging the private sector for demonstrations and expected to be resolved at the project consolidation as per the recommendations of MTR.
Industry is very keen on biomass energy option and many companies have already installed plants without project inputs. However, project expects to introduce demand driven, modern bio-energy technologies as demonstrations after the conclusion of the project consolidation

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Output 4.2: Established information of biomass energy technologies for fuel-switching in industries
Technical information provided to potential industries interested in fuel switching
Number and amount of investments resulting from the matchmaking and training events

target.comment:
Manual prepared and disseminated widely through project partners and media, on successful gasification applications and challenges, remedial actions and technical support by 2014
At least 24 companies have taken BET-related investment decisions (in addition to the companies directly supported by the project).

actual.comment:
Not initiated yet. Expected to review the technology selection at the project consolidation as per the MTR recommendation.
This activity has not been formally commenced. However, there are many companies opting for biomass energy BETs. The project is working on developing partnership with the industry chambers to identify companies that need technical support to implement modern bioenergy technologies and assist them.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Output 4.3: Completed trainings and research aimed at improving services to promote fuel-switching in industry
1) Number of trainings workshops held for staff of companies adopting BET

target.comment: At least 10 events, organized with 250 participants in total over 2014- 2017 from technology and service providing companies; At least 80 staff (in particular operators from the participating companies) trained in O&M.

actual.comment:
One workshop was conducted by SLSEA, it was well attended and well received by the participants.
Workshop was on “Biomass Energy in Industrial Applications” inclusive of a practical session - Engineers or managerial level employees in bulk biomass consuming industries, electricity power plants, university lecturers, government stakeholders (@ MAS Fabric Park, Thulhiriya, Feb 19 -21, 2015, 33 participants).

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Output 4.4: Established information exchange system
Number of companies that use the database on BET-using industries, national and international technology suppliers and service providers.
Performance standard formulated; number of projects that are designed in compliance with the standards.

actual.comment:
SLSEA has taken initial steps to develop the database, data collection and initial discussions with a software development company.
Not initiated yet.

location.name: Sri Lanka
location.activity-description: implemented national level through the Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma programmes targeting 12 vulnerable Districts.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Increase the resilience of communities to climate change induced hazards through integration of climate smart policies and actions in to development planning and budgeting.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
No of sectoral adaptation strategies identified by the project approved and budgeted by the Departments of Agriculture, Agrarian Development, Coastal Conservation and Ministry of Economic Development
Climate risk assessment is an integral part of development planning at national and district level

baseline.comment:
< 05
climate risk assessment is non-existent

target.comment:
20 strategies and their associated actions implemented
Climate risk assessment included in planning processes for VDPs, district development plans and Gama Neguma/Divi Neguma national Programmes in 12 vulnerable districts

actual.comment:
It is too early to report the progress against the objective especially because the IP Ministry was dissolved 4 months after the project started. The project was then re-assigned in June 2015, 5 months later.
Nevertheless, during this period the project was able to identify a set of key adaptation actions with relevant government departments.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: National rural development programmes Divi Neguma and Gama Neguma integrate climate risk information and adaptation measures in 12 vulnerable districts

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No of Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma projects modified through climate risk assessments at GN and Divisional Level

target.comment: 150 Gama Neguma Projects. 5 Divi Neguma Strategies including crop selection for home gardens, perennial crops for small commercial farms livestock choice, water and soil management incentives inland/freshwater fishery

actual.comment: Divinaguma programme was influenced to implement adaptive livelihood measures and incorporate climate and disaster resilience into the existing programs. For example, two diversified livelihood development programs (i.e. poultry farming and cattle farming) were promoted in order to minimize dependency on water.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: National, district, divisional and local technical staff have sufficient technical capacity to identify and integrate climate risk considerations in designing, approving and implementing development projects under the Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma programmes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of staff (disaggregated by gender) within national, district, divisional and local planning units in 12 vulnerable districts reported to apply climate risk assessment tools and methods to new rural investment projects
No of stakeholder groups reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at national, district and village levels

baseline.comment:
0
0
(lack of awareness has been reported as a major barrier during stakeholder consultations)

target.comment: National officers of NPD, MoED, MoF = 20, Technical agencies and department= 50, District Planning and Samurdhi officers= 75, Village Mobilisers= 300, Local Authority Technical Officers =120, Trainers trained =15. Key stakeholder groups listed below report higher level of awareness measured by before and after survey-Officers of National Planning, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Economic Development- Divi Neguma Task Force at National and District level, District Planning Units, Divisional Planning Units, Village mobilisers-communities in risk prone GN units

actual.comment: The progress against this outcome is low because of the earlier mentioned political issues. However, to date the awareness of 20 government officers from technical agencies and departments (agrarian services department, provincial department of agriculture, Department of veterinary medicine and animal health) was enhanced on climate change adaptation in development planning.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Concrete adaptation actions defined and implemented in selected vulnerable villages/ village clusters in the 12 target districts to increase resilience of rural development programmes to climatic risks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
% increase in annual income of farmers (disaggregated by gender) as a result of project introduced adaptation measures implemented in home gardens and small farms
Total value of community driven rural infrastructure built following building codes and construction controls and guidelines for climate and disaster risk reduction

baseline.comment:
annual income = or < USD1500 in target farm households
0

target.comment:
15% increase against baseline by 2015
20% increase against baseline by 2016
USD 2.25 million
At least 50% over the baseline value of Gama Neguma Investment in five villages per districts

actual.comment:
To date, the project was able to set the ground for implementing climate change adaptation actions by identifying key economic sectors (including minor irrigation and agriculture development) and adaptation priorities.
The project team was able to set the ground for collaborative work between the Department of Agrarian Development and Provincial Department of Agriculture. The project initiated implementation of minor irrigation cascade system development, micro irrigation development and agriculture development. However, some planned activities could not be completed given the dissolution of the Ministry of Economic Development, the identified IP.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of policy actions on social integration and reconciliation implemented. 2. Number of people benefiting from mobile documentation clinics through this project 3. Number of events conducted to sensitize public on social integration

baseline.comment: 1. Two Policies in place: i. National Policy Framework for Social Integration launched; National action-plan under formulation; ii. Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission report and action-plan in place (2013) 2. 0 ( 2013) 3. 1 (Social Integration Week since 2012)

target.comment: 1. 3 2. 8,000 people 3. 3 events

actual.comment: 1. 0 2. 15,724 people 3. 4. They are (1) national kite festival, (2) Tri-Lingual Social Integration Calendar for school children about numerically small ethnic groups, (3) development of 25-episode teledrama on social integration, (4) Empowerment of Women as Agents of Change for social integration (40 women trained)

target.comment: 1. 2 2. 3,000 people 3. 4 events

actual.comment: 1. 0 2. Estimated 3000 legal documents including birth, death and marriage certificates were issued for members from the estate sector communities. 3. 5 initiatives undertaken- the youth empowerment for social integration initiative was conducted, a programme to mobilize volunteers to provide translation support was conducted and a pool of volunteer translators identified, a dialogue programme for journalists on social integration and reconciliation was conducted, follow up initiatives with the women leaders empowered through support in 2014, were supported to work on social integration initiatives on the ground, and exposure to teachers was provided on the topic of social integration and promote co-existence.

location.name: Anuradhapura District
location.activity-description: Anuradhapura

location.name: Ratnapura District
location.activity-description: Ratnapura

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. District Case flow Management Committees (CFM) established 2. Number of priority cases identified to be addressed in three area models( courts, prosecution) 3. National legal aid policy developed 4. Number of land cases handled by dispute resolution mechanisms 5. Sector wide National coordination mechanism operational (identified through the national sector wide Steering Committee) 6. Number of key pieces of legislation consolidated and translated into both official languages

baseline.comment: 1. No Case F low Management Committee existing (2013) 2. No system to identify priority cases (2013) 3. There is no Legal Aid Policy ( 2013 ) 4. Dispute resolution mechanisms for land cases do not exist ( 2013) 5. No Sector wide Steering Committee ( 2013 ) 6. Legislation has not been consolidated or translated into local languages ( 2013 )

target.comment: 1. 1 of 3 Case flow Management Committees ( CFM ) established 2. Develop criteria for identifying priority cases for all three area models 3. Develop Terms Of Reference and Identify consultant to develop National Legal Aid Policy 4. consultations with key stakeholders on formation of special mediation boards for land cases 5. Justice Sector Steering Committee established 6. 02 pieces of legislature have been consolidated and translated

actual.comment: 1. Case flow Management Committees (CFM )were not established, initial discussions were held at national level to bring stakeholders together 2. Criteria was not developed 3. Terms Of Reference was developed and consultant was identified 4. Key stakeholders from the Justice sector, civil societies' members and key international organizations have been consulted on formation of special mediation boards, plans on way forward was agreed upon 5. The steering committee was not established. Initial discussions with key stakeholders have take place 6. Consolidation and translation of (1) Penal Code and (2) Criminal Procedure code is completed

target.comment: 1. 2 of 3Case flow Management Committees (CFM) committees established 2. Priority cases identified in area model 01 3. Draft Legal Aid Policy ready for review with key Stakeholders 4. Formation of special mediation boards for land cases 5. Sector Coordination plan identified 6. 02 more pieces of legislature have been consolidated and translated

actual.comment: 1. Case Flow Management Committee established in 1 area model. 2. Priority cases were not identified in the area model as the consultation processes continued through out 2015 and the study to assess the blocks in the case flow faced several challenges to getting off the ground. 3. The Draft Legal Aid Policy has been finalized and provided to the Ministry of Justice to prepare for submission to the Cabinet of Ministers. 4. Following the gazette being issued calling for the establishment of special land mediation boards, UNDP supported the primary step of raising awareness on the gazette and role of the boards in the pilot districts. This is a pre-requisite before calling for nominations of individuals to serve on the special land mediation boards. UNDP worked collaboratively with the Asia Foundation in this regard as TAF is preparing to provide training for the Board members, once established. 6. Translation and consolidation of the Evidence Ordinance and Judicature Act was initiated in 2015 and the process is on-going.
